positive.review:
Playing this after WWE 2K22, I have to say ‚Äî it‚Äôs still the best one in the series. I‚Äôve enjoyed WWE 2K24 and WWE 2K25 very much, However there are still dispite it going in the right direction ,still many flaws and outdated gameplay:

‚úÖ The Good:

- Chain wrestling makes a return.
- Massive roster.
- New hairstyles in the Creation Suite (especially happy they brought back some older ones).
- Graphics are really solid.
- The AI is a lot smarter now ‚Äî they actually complete taunts before going for moves, etc.
- New game modes have been added and are a nice touch.

‚ùå The Bad:

- The Island content is limited to "next-gen" consoles ‚Äî PC is next-gen too!

- Creation Suite limitations:
I‚Äôm pleading with 2K ‚Äî please overhaul this mode. It‚Äôs extremely outdated, especially with the face scans and morphs. We need: More customization options, More hairstyles, More clothing options for female wrestlers, Fixes for attire parts that glitch based on hairstyles, Ability to customize in-game characters (hair, makeup, face paint, lip gloss, eyelashes, eyes, body morphs, etc.), This is such a core part of the game, and it‚Äôs overwhelmingly disappointing that after four games, there‚Äôs still no major improvement.

- Universe Mode:
What have the developers done here? Respectfully ‚Äî it‚Äôs a mess. I want to build rivalries, pick actions, and shape stories. Instead, it‚Äôs repetitive, copy-paste matches with no triple-threat rivalries. Royal Rumble rivalries feel flat. They have all the tools to make this the best mode in the game ‚Äî even better than Showcase. I want to feel like I‚Äôm running the company: booking surprise returns, hearing commentary react to comebacks or injuries. Please bring back custom promos ‚Äî make them interactive! It doesn‚Äôt need voice acting, just immersion. You can do it, 2K. I believe in you.

- MyFaction:
Terrible. Full stop. Locked behind paywalls for ‚Äúpersona cards‚Äù that take forever to earn. It‚Äôs boring and pointless. We all wanted Road to WrestleMania (RTWM) ‚Äî instead, we got this. Get rid of it. If you want monetization, just do a ¬£10 battle pass for cosmetics ‚Äî not this grindfest.

- Showcase:
It‚Äôs okay. I‚Äôm a hardcore women‚Äôs wrestling fan (as you can tell from my Creation Suite rant), but that one random ladder match for MITB? Easily the worst Showcase match. Not terrible overall, but please ‚Äî more women‚Äôs matches next time.

- The Island (again):
Oh wait‚Ä¶ we can‚Äôt even play it on PC. If you‚Äôre advertising a ‚Äúnew mode,‚Äù there should be a price difference if we can‚Äôt access it. I‚Äôve watched gameplay and reviews ‚Äî doesn‚Äôt look like we missed much though.

- MyRise:
First year I didn‚Äôt finish it. I just don‚Äôt like intergender wrestling ‚Äî not because of the gender dynamic, but because it doesn‚Äôt happen in WWE now. Instead of two separate stories, they merged them lazily.
Here‚Äôs an idea, 2K: stop releasing yearly games and actually spend time making something inventive.

- AI improvements to matches and gameplay:
Managers are hopeless at supporting during matches. Please amend the rope-break animations so the referee can always see them, and stop the referee from colliding with a wrestler‚Äôs head during pin counts ‚Äî the ref should get there in time to make the count. Make managers interfere more dynamically: have them interact with each other, perform shady actions at ringside, and play believable win/lose reactions (e.g., an animation of disbelief when their wrestler loses a pin). In the Royal Rumble, members of the same faction shouldn‚Äôt be constantly attacking each other ‚Äî they‚Äôre stablemates, not random opponents. Add more betrayals in Universe Mode (or at least give the option for storyline betrayals). Make Money in the Bank cash-ins more meaningful and better utilized by the AI. For example, with the AI scaled to high, I played the same match 10 times and the MITB briefcase holder only managed a successful cash-in on the 9th attempt. Please think more carefully about AI behaviour and match intent, 2K ‚Äî come on.

üí° Recommendations for the Next Game:

- Creation Suite Overhaul: More hairstyles, makeup, clothes, attire pieces, customizable morphs, and body templates. Let us edit in-game superstars (hair, makeup, etc.).

- Universe Mode: Needs a massive overhaul.

- Create-a-Finisher: Please bring this back ‚Äî it was so much fun!

- Create-a-Story: Another immersive fan-favourite that should return.

- RTWM: Bring it back ‚Äî and get rid of MyFaction.

- Separate Women‚Äôs and Men‚Äôs Showcases: Appease both fan bases.

- Legends Contracts: Keep them active! If Kelly Kelly or Torrie Wilson aren‚Äôt in the next game, I‚Äôll riot (kidding‚Ä¶ mostly). Also bring back Jazz, Luna Vachon, Ivory, Retro Molly Holly, Retro Lita, Retro Trish, and AJ Lee.

2.5/5

Overall, an improvement on 2k24. Many positives added to improve the overall loop and speed everything up. And boy is the game faster. Matches feel faster, the game runs smoother and overall there is just more excitement to go around. I found the story mode to be a vast improvement to the 2k24 story, though maybe not as wild as the 2k23 story we were treated to. The showcase mode is actually one of the weaker ones with tons of content locked behind RNG heavy objectives that force you into a very grindy gameplay loop with the hopes of completing the objective. I gave up finishing this mode when they hid an unlock behind an objective to force 4 seperate characters to bleed in a match. Bleeding is a very RNG heavy mechanic and only happens with damage to the head so.... Not particularly fun to play honestly. The GM is there... I actually haven't played that mode yet. I know they added CM punk as a GM and a bunch of other variety characters there but... I just don't care about that. Universe mode is overall better, the promo feature is cool but unfortunately very very limited. Some things were improved but mostly more of the same of what we had last time. Finally, the card game mode or "MyFaction" is considerably improved upon from the previous game but still feels like an unneeded edition to an otherwise content filled game. I understand the need to want a live service model in a modern game but maybe just like... release skin packs instead of hiding them behind a still incredibly grindy game mode that is not particularly skill based and is also itself cluttered with like 5 different play modes like towers, and weekly challenges, and a roguelike mode, and a pvp mode. Not to mention the games actual PVP mode. basically MyFaction doesn't seem like it's needed in these games anymore. Finally, the PC version not recieving "The Island" game mode is a little disappointing. The growing issues between PC and console trying to coexist in this new era of crossplay are more apparent here then in most other places. A HUGE selling point of this game is just not available to a quarter of the games player base and that is a letdown. Overall, the game, at its base, is fine. a slight improvement in the core gameplay loop to the previous game. The new match types are cool, the updated roster is fine, and the character creator is ok. If I gave the previous game a 5/10, this game is a solid 5.5. 

A final note. With all 5(6) Dlc packs now out, a moment to reflect on those.
Unfortunately, this game has the WORST DLC lineup amongst all the games. While Abyss and the Great Khali are welcome editions, the average wrestling fan does not give a crap about KSI in a prime bottle, Shaq or the disaster that was the Kevin Scott fiasco. Also, while the first DLC pack had plenty of women, the rest of the DLC was incredibly lacking in womens wrestlers. A huge letdown. NXT felt completely ignored in the DLC. and in general, the DLC for this game does not feel like it was made with the modern wrestling landscape in mind what so ever. No Joe Hendry? No Rusev? No Rey Fenix? Anyway, there's my gripe on the mess that was the DLC. 

Purchase 2k25 on sale if you want. at this point, with 2k26 only a few months from being announced, it may be best to hope that the next game in the series addresses the biggest issues this game brought about. One thing for sure, 2k26 will finally feature an update to WWE's roster to cut the dozen's of wrestlers no longer on contract like Indi Hartwell and Tegan Nox.

WWE 2K25 hits the ring with confidence. The Showcase mode is the best it‚Äôs been‚Äîwell-edited, hype, and packed with moments that make you want to replay bouts to nail every objective. The roster is stacked and feels alive thanks to strong presentation and entrances, and the gameplay finally threads the needle between sim weight and pick-up-and-play fun. Strikes feel crisp, grapples have satisfying snap, and reversal timing rewards practice without punishing newcomers.

I do have one wish: please don‚Äôt sunset the online servers a year in. This entry deserves a long tail. Keep building on this foundation‚Äîtuning balance, adding match types, and supporting community creations‚Äîand 2K can keep the momentum rolling.

Verdict: Best Showcase to date, amazing roster depth, and great in-ring feel. If 2K keeps supporting it, this could be the era-defining WWE game.

I don‚Äôt even know where to start‚Ä¶ maybe from the little piggy bank I used to fill with coins every week.
Every single coin was for one purpose ‚Äî to buy the next WWE game. Not just because I love gaming, but because WWE has always been my life, my dream, my fire.

When WWE 2K25 first released, I couldn‚Äôt afford it. I watched gameplay videos, trailers, and fan reactions every night before bed. I used to imagine myself playing it, hearing the crowd cheer as my created superstar walked down the ramp. But reality hit ‚Äî my wallet was empty.

Still, I never gave up. I kept saving. And one day, when the Steam sale arrived, I finally bought it.
That moment ‚Äî clicking ‚ÄúPurchase‚Äù ‚Äî felt like winning a championship belt. I smiled so wide that day, not because of the game itself, but because it represented something bigger. It was a small victory for the kid who never stopped dreaming.

But this story goes deeper than a game.
A few months ago, I had a terrible accident that tore the ligament in my left shoulder. I had to go through three surgeries just to fix it. Before that, I was actually training hard to become a real wrestler. I even sent my body pictures to a wrestling community, and they told me I had potential ‚Äî that I could really join the WWE someday.

I was so close.
They told me the only challenge was getting from Bangladesh to the USA. I was already thinking about how to make it happen ‚Äî planning, preparing, dreaming. Then the accident came out of nowhere and destroyed everything I had worked for. The pain wasn‚Äôt just physical; it was emotional. I cried so many nights thinking about how I lost my chance because of something I couldn‚Äôt control.

For a while, I thought it was over. That maybe I was never meant to live that dream.

But then, I started playing WWE 2K25.
And something changed inside me.

Every time I play, every time I hear the crowd roar, every time my character wins a match ‚Äî I feel alive again. I feel like I‚Äôm in that ring for real. The graphics, the entrances, the movement, the commentary ‚Äî it all feels so real that it brings me peace. I can close my eyes and imagine myself under those bright lights, raising my arm in victory again.

This game isn‚Äôt just entertainment for me. It‚Äôs a second chance ‚Äî a way to keep my passion burning until I‚Äôm ready to step into the ring again in real life.

Because yes, I‚Äôm still recovering. My shoulder is healing. I‚Äôm getting stronger every day. And deep down, I still believe that one day, I‚Äôll stand inside a WWE ring ‚Äî for real this time.

I don‚Äôt know what the future holds. Maybe I‚Äôll make it, maybe I won‚Äôt. But one thing is for sure ‚Äî I‚Äôll never stop fighting.

WWE 2K25 reminded me that the fire in my heart didn‚Äôt die ‚Äî it was just waiting for a comeback.

So yeah‚Ä¶ this isn‚Äôt just a review from a gamer.
This is a message from someone who lost everything, but found hope again through the thing they love most.

Thank you, WWE 2K25.
You gave me back a piece of my dream. ‚ù§Ô∏è

I have played WWE 2k16, 2k19, 2k22, a few other old WWE games like Smackdown vs Raw, Day of Reckoning 2, No Mercy and I have also played FPWW (Fire Pro Wrestling World)... though I give a thumbs up, please consider this as a MIXED REVIEW.

GOOD things: lots of customization, now including arenas, game rules, title belts, mixed matches, etc. Decent single player modes and a fair ammount of unlockable stuff (not necessarily paid or DLC). Honestly, one of the least buggy and better developed 2K wrestling games (probably the best so far), considering the level of customization and the ammount of content in it. If you're a WWE fan or you simply enjoy a custom wrestling experience, I totally recommend this one.

BAD things are the obvious ones... pretty much same ideas and problems from the previous 2K games, except this one's less buggy. However, the game focuses too much on graphics and too little on improving or inovating the main mechanics: weird reversals, weirder submission and pinfall mechanics, and overall weird model behavior (like objects getting stuck or characters not going exactly where you want them to). Difficulty tweaking may help fix most of the experience, but don't expect anything too different or mind blowing compared to the previous 2K releases. And, as always, online multiplayer is kinda laggy and few people play (plus who TF said timing mechanics was good for this game's online mode!?).

So... I DO recommend this game, out of all other 2K games. Be aware, tho, that you'll need MORE than the minimum requirements to properly run it. Here hoping WWE keeps working on this game instead of releasing 2k26 in a rush...

I have been an avid WWE fan since I was a kid (Cena is the GOAT); however, I feel disappointed after playing this game for how shitty its showcase is (the mainest element in a WWE game for me). Additionally, the soundtrack at the main menu sucks, Brock is a DLC (WOW!), and no island of relevancy on PC? 

 I recommend you wait for a game that has a full showcase about John Cena.

[h1] Things Need to Change [/h1]

If your're looking for improved game play then you'll get it here but, it's nothing major. You'll see more visual damage on wrestlers throughout the match and the chain wrestling is a nice addition but, it's not worth up for. I have played WWE games for over 20 years and understand the lack of major changes to the core game is normal for a few years so I'm not expecting that. 

The issue is that the rest of the game doesn't feel any better. The universe mode is in need of a major change but, that didn't happen this year. The GM Mode they brought back in 23 still feels underwhelming. The MyRise is too difficult to play because the storyline is so horrible. The Smackdown vs Raw games had the right idea with allowing you to play as different wrestlers for a career mode. This one just feels like a waste of time. 

The Showcase mode is easily the worse one of them all. The matches from the Samoan Bloodline weren't picked well. They missed out on an opportunity to have The Rock vs Brock Lesnar or Roman Reigns vs Brock Lesnar (The biggest feud of Reigns career). This is easily the most uninteresting Showcase of the WWE 2k series. 

I have major issues with this game as far unlockables. We used to be able to pay for everything unlocked. Now while I don't agree with charging fans for unlocks, I don't mind paying extra for it. Too many wrestlers are locked to MyFaction and MyRise. To unlock 2015 Randy Orton and Scott Steiner, you are forced to play through career mode. For certain wrestlers, you need to play through career mode twice. How is that fair? Why force that on players? 

They recently brought John Cena 03 and modern Brock Lesnar back through "Farewell Tour" DLC. This was not worth the extra $15. I really wanted to play as Brock Lesnar again and so I picked this up. Brock Lesnar didn't come with wrestling attire and I had to download a community an attire from Community Creations. 

I even tried MyFation this year and unlocked 2010 John Cena and he didn't come with in ring attire either. I used the extra MyFaction points I got from the Bloodline Edition to get him and felt like I got ripped off. I hate this mode and I tried to push through to unlock things but, I stoppped because it's too much of a grind. They put retro AJ Styles on there but, I wasn't going to play for hours to unlock him and I already paid over $100 for the game so I didn't feel like paying extra. 

For the first time ever, I bought some VC points to try and unlock Booker T 01. He's been a MyFaction exclusive for years. I will never buy VC points or touch this MyFaction mode ever again. It feels like a cheap mobile game and isn't fun at all. Some people wanted "The Island" on PC. The console version of the game made Goldberg an exclusive to that mode? So even if we did have access to "The Island" we'd have to grind through that mode to unlock him. 

Things have got ridiculous and I regret purchasing this game. Is the core game solid? Yes. Can you still have fun with it? Sure. I still can't recommend it because aside from locking wrestlers to these cheap modes, the overall game doesn't do anything special.

Overall, this game is pretty good, and to me it's the best wrestling game I've played in a while. I'm only able to compare it to 2k19 and 2k23, but it's good enough to get me to keep coming back and playing. I still wouldn't rank it above classic games or FirePro, but for a modern WWE game, it's not too bad with the exception of what must be a bug with Windows 11.

I don't recommend the game on Windows 11 until a fix is available. Based on my research, this bug has been present since around the time of launch. What makes it frustrating is that consistently almost 15% of the time I launch the game, it completely freezes my computer. None of the tricks recommended have worked. For a while, I was able to press the windows key and eventually bring the game back up, but the freezing still occurs albeit on a possibly less frequent basis. I haven't played any other game that will force me to perform a hard reboot on my PC.

I would buy this on sale, but I strongly recommend not buying it until the bug is fixed.

Regarding the gameplay and everything else:

I've loved wrestling games for my whole life. I feel like there still isn't anything comparable to the golden age of games on the n64 or ps2. I'm relatively new to the 2K series and disliked the last two games I played - 2k19 and 2k23. I think the controls in 19 were very foreign to me, and in 23 what really stood out was the roster and music plus the still confusing controls. For 25, the controls feel a bit more familiar and easier to pick up and play. That said, it is still difficult to get timing down on reversals and play on harder difficulties. This never felt like a problem in the Smackdown or even Smackdown vs Raw games where I would play on the highest difficulties as well as normal. 

Something that stood out to me here was the story. It definitely felt better than in the other two 2K games I played. I thought myRise was fun, but it ended so soon. I also thought the twist in it was unexpected and kinda ruined my perception of the CAWs I made. It was surprising that I had to make two CAWs for the story mode, but that wasn't a problem as I generally make at least three CAWs each game. I would have liked a more open story mode or an option to do different things each time I replayed it. I don't plan on replaying this story mode and find it lacking.

This game is worse than the last one. The roster is the biggest and most locked behind paywalls and grindwalls. You go to play, and three-quarters of the fighter selection consists of question marks and grayed-out names, and you can only chose some modern, uninteresting wrestlers. All the legends are hidden behind the grindwall. SuperCharger DLC for unlock real wrestlers without grinding, overpriced as hell. The showcase is lazy and boring, there aren't even traditional cutscenes leading up to the fight‚Äîwhat a shame?! They obviously decided not to invest in this mode. The console and PC versions are separated by functionality! The Island mode is unavailable on PC, without which you can't get about 80 wrestlers, including Goldberg and Bella! Are you seriously doing this in 2025?? The graphics are worse than they were in 2024! The wrestlers look like rubber dolls; it's a huge downgrade, especially when compared side by side with the last game. That awful patchy hair again, like a PlayStation 3 game!  How can you release something like this in 2025? Can't you see what games look like now? Some fighters from the previous game were removed for some reason, like modern-day Steve Austin, who had a really cool skin in 2024. Why did they remove him? The improvements are very few and have little impact. They added an optional third-person mode, which is fun to play with, but it's inconvenient to use constantly due to the changing controls. Updated blood effects? Blood is completely unnecessary in this game; it looks out of place. Wrestlers now don't bleed like in the 1990s. The most they get is a little blood in the mouth from a split lip or minor abrasions. If the developers had done the same, it would have been much more realistic than those ridiculous gallons of blood all over the head and half the body. Those bloody streams on women look especially stupid. So I just turn off the blood. The updated bruises on the body also look unrealistic. Usually, wrestlers only get red spots on their bodies, not those maroon streaks all over, like they've been hit by a truck. Chain wrestling looks funny, but only the first time, and then it starts to get annoying, disrupting the dynamics of the fight. That minigame with finding a point and waiting for the red circle to fill is very long. The only interesting improvement is intergender matches, but that's not enough to justify the cost of the entire game. This could easily be added with a patch or a mod to any game in the series. This game is very disappointing to me; it feels like that failure that happened between 2k19 and 2k20. Unless 2k changes the engine, I will never buy another game in this series. I've had enough.

You get 150-180 points in a single match, while the prices in the store are incredibly high, reaching hundreds of thousands. Grinding is everywhere in this game; it's so intense that it practically should be FTP. I bought this game to play a couple of matches with my favorite characters from the 1990s and 2000s in the evening after work, but they're all locked behind a grindwall. Unlocking one legendary character costs 1000 points, a 5-star match gives no more than 225 points, and such a match lasts about 20 minutes. So, you need five 20-minute matches to unlock a single fighter, like Shawn Michaels. But I can't spend two hours a day on this game to unlock the fighters I want to play. I‚Äôve been a loyal fan of the WWE 2K series for years. I‚Äôve bought every release, supported the game through all the ups and downs, and hoped each new entry would finally show that 2K listens to its community. But WWE 2K25 has proven that they absolutely don‚Äôt.

Let‚Äôs start with the most frustrating part ‚Äî the pricing and DLC situation. I purchased one of the most expensive bundles, thinking it would come with everything. For that kind of price, it should. But somehow, 2K still expects us to pay extra for DLC packs that are either delayed, incomplete, or split across different platforms. Console players get more content and certain perks, while others are left wondering why they paid the same (or more) for less.

It‚Äôs honestly insulting. Every year, 2K claims they ‚Äúlisten to the fans,‚Äù but the product says otherwise. Fans have been crystal clear about what we want: fair pricing, complete editions that actually include all future DLC, better communication about what‚Äôs included, and genuine gameplay improvements. Instead, we get the same recycled talking points and half-promises that never amount to anything.

The worst part is how tone-deaf the marketing has become. They hype up ‚Äúloyalty rewards‚Äù and ‚Äúspecial editions,‚Äù but it all feels like smoke and mirrors when the people who spend the most money still don‚Äôt get the full experience. There‚Äôs no consistency, no respect for long-time supporters, and no sense that 2K understands what makes this community passionate in the first place.

Gameplay-wise, sure, it‚Äôs fine. The core wrestling mechanics are serviceable, but after years of minimal innovation, it feels stagnant. The flashy trailers and minor tweaks don‚Äôt change the fact that this series has lost its soul. I have been an avid WWE fan since I was a kid (Cena is the GOAT); however, I feel disappointed after playing this game for how shitty its showcase is (the mainest element in a WWE game for me). Additionally, the soundtrack at the main menu sucks, Brock is a DLC (WOW!), and no island of relevancy on PC? 

 I recommend you wait for a game that has a full showcase about John Cena.

[h1] Things Need to Change [/h1]

If your're looking for improved game play then you'll get it here but, it's nothing major. You'll see more visual damage on wrestlers throughout the match and the chain wrestling is a nice addition but, it's not worth up for. I have played WWE games for over 20 years and understand the lack of major changes to the core game is normal for a few years so I'm not expecting that. 

The issue is that the rest of the game doesn't feel any better. The universe mode is in need of a major change but, that didn't happen this year. The GM Mode they brought back in 23 still feels underwhelming. The MyRise is too difficult to play because the storyline is so horrible. The Smackdown vs Raw games had the right idea with allowing you to play as different wrestlers for a career mode. This one just feels like a waste of time. 

The Showcase mode is easily the worse one of them all. The matches from the Samoan Bloodline weren't picked well. They missed out on an opportunity to have The Rock vs Brock Lesnar or Roman Reigns vs Brock Lesnar (The biggest feud of Reigns career). This is easily the most uninteresting Showcase of the WWE 2k series. 

I have major issues with this game as far unlockables. We used to be able to pay for everything unlocked. Now while I don't agree with charging fans for unlocks, I don't mind paying extra for it. Too many wrestlers are locked to MyFaction and MyRise. To unlock 2015 Randy Orton and Scott Steiner, you are forced to play through career mode. For certain wrestlers, you need to play through career mode twice. How is that fair? Why force that on players? 

They recently brought John Cena 03 and modern Brock Lesnar back through "Farewell Tour" DLC. This was not worth the extra $15. I really wanted to play as Brock Lesnar again and so I picked this up. Brock Lesnar didn't come with wrestling attire and I had to download a community an attire from Community Creations. 

I even tried MyFation this year and unlocked 2010 John Cena and he didn't come with in ring attire either. I used the extra MyFaction points I got from the Bloodline Edition to get him and felt like I got ripped off. I hate this mode and I tried to push through to unlock things but, I stoppped because it's too much of a grind. They put retro AJ Styles on there but, I wasn't going to play for hours to unlock him and I already paid over $100 for the game so I didn't feel like paying extra. 

For the first time ever, I bought some VC points to try and unlock Booker T 01. He's been a MyFaction exclusive for years. I will never buy VC points or touch this MyFaction mode ever again. It feels like a cheap mobile game and isn't fun at all. Some people wanted "The Island" on PC. The console version of the game made Goldberg an exclusive to that mode? So even if we did have access to "The Island" we'd have to grind through that mode to unlock him. 

Things have got ridiculous and I regret purchasing this game. Is the core game solid? Yes. Can you still have fun with it? Sure. I still can't recommend it because aside from locking wrestlers to these cheap modes, the overall game doesn't do anything special.

Overall, this game is pretty good, and to me it's the best wrestling game I've played in a while. I'm only able to compare it to 2k19 and 2k23, but it's good enough to get me to keep coming back and playing. I still wouldn't rank it above classic games or FirePro, but for a modern WWE game, it's not too bad with the exception of what must be a bug with Windows 11.

I don't recommend the game on Windows 11 until a fix is available. Based on my research, this bug has been present since around the time of launch. What makes it frustrating is that consistently almost 15% of the time I launch the game, it completely freezes my computer. None of the tricks recommended have worked. For a while, I was able to press the windows key and eventually bring the game back up, but the freezing still occurs albeit on a possibly less frequent basis. I haven't played any other game that will force me to perform a hard reboot on my PC.

I would buy this on sale, but I strongly recommend not buying it until the bug is fixed.

Regarding the gameplay and everything else:

I've loved wrestling games for my whole life. I feel like there still isn't anything comparable to the golden age of games on the n64 or ps2. I'm relatively new to the 2K series and disliked the last two games I played - 2k19 and 2k23. I think the controls in 19 were very foreign to me, and in 23 what really stood out was the roster and music plus the still confusing controls. For 25, the controls feel a bit more familiar and easier to pick up and play. That said, it is still difficult to get timing down on reversals and play on harder difficulties. This never felt like a problem in the Smackdown or even Smackdown vs Raw games where I would play on the highest difficulties as well as normal. 

Something that stood out to me here was the story. It definitely felt better than in the other two 2K games I played. I thought myRise was fun, but it ended so soon. I also thought the twist in it was unexpected and kinda ruined my perception of the CAWs I made. It was surprising that I had to make two CAWs for the story mode, but that wasn't a problem as I generally make at least three CAWs each game. I would have liked a more open story mode or an option to do different things each time I replayed it. I don't plan on replaying this story mode and find it lacking.

I don't like Showcase and generally don't play these modes where you are forced to be a specific superstar. I played a few but found it not that fun.

I love the online creator suite and have enjoyed adding CAWs and brands into my Universe, but as others have mentioned, the PC is not currently considered a current gen system which is incredibly stupid. The steam release should definitely have access to the same content consoles have.

GM mode was great. I loved being able to play as a brand and compete against friends. It's cool having a draft, and I wish this was in Universe. I think I would like a few more options to tweak budgets and contracts more. It can be pretty hard to move into a new year when talent leaves. I've caught the booking bug as a result of this and am looking forward to trying the other Steam booking games.

I'm basically only playing Universe. It's fun to have your own shows and run everything simming and playing matches as you go. The biggest complaint I have is that I wish we could have away to have tournaments in the mode without having to have King of the Ring PLEs. It was hard at first to get used to the calendar and schedule events, but I recommend spending hours and removing all lives and PLEs and then making your own. It would be helpful to also have an easier way to copy match cards to other lives as the default is generally a few singles and tag matches, and this makes it rather cumbersome to make hardcore PLEs and lives.

This is definitely a barebones review, but I wanted to explain a few areas I like and dislike while calling attention to the buggy state of the game on PC.

Review of WWE 2K25 ‚Äì What‚Äôs Good and What‚Äôs Not

I've got sufficient time with WWE 2K25 on Steam to actually have a real opinion, and I've got to say this game is a weird blend of fun and outright frustration. On the fly it looks smooth, the presentation pops visually, and where everything comes together just right, it actually feels as though you are part of a WWE match. When you get past the surface and are spending time with a host of modes though, the flaws become evident all around you, at least on PC.

First and foremost, the gameplay, because that‚Äôs the foundation of any wrestling game. Mechanically, it‚Äôs good. Animations are neater than years ago, strikes have a nice impact, and the timing of bouts feels more like you‚Äôd see on TV. Chain grapples chain together smoothly, reversals are quick, and at a casual level you can grab and go. But the AI this year is flat-out busted at times. They reverse nearly every grapple you attempt and try, and it doesn‚Äôt feel like masterful counter-wrestling, it feels like cheap scripting. You can whip the hell out of them for a good solid 15 minutes or however long and they still kick out at two like they just got off the bus at ringside. There‚Äôs no realism or balance to it and it kills the momentum. What should be dramatic near-falls become frustration because you know they are going to kick out no matter what. Difficulty needs to be earned and not rammed through via unfair mechanisms.

My other big letdown has been with MyRise mode. Always a high point of the series, build a character, progress through story modes, see how your decisions impact your career. But with 2K25 it seems trimmed back and dull. Cutscenes play through themselves much too quick, the branches of lore are not especially significant, and the sheer amount of material is much less with 2K25 compared with older games. It feels a step back and not a step forward. After a few hours I found myself tired of it and not eagerly looking forward to continuing. For a mode intended to keep you hooked long-term, that‚Äôs a big problem.

On top of everything else, being a PC player this year has felt like punishment. The Island mode, one of the biggest and most hyped new features, isn‚Äôt even an option through Steam. We pay console price and receive a console experience. We don‚Äôt receive the full package. It makes the whole version of the game a ‚Äúlast-gen port‚Äù and thus an improper release. All of that from one absent feature has the capacity to enrage some and honestly, I don‚Äôt fault them. And then consider that the Community Creations are locked off as well, so we can‚Äôt download the same custom wrestlers and arenas as console fans and it just makes the PC one seem second class. For a franchise that survives off of customization, it‚Äôs a setback.

And then there‚Äôs stability. I‚Äôve played through a number of crashes during games, and a couple of times the game has frozen my entire system and forced a reboot. In Windows 11, and especially since the 24H2 update, this seems like a common problem. It‚Äôs bad enough experiencing bugs while you are just playing the game, but having the game cause issues with your entire PC system is unacceptable. And don‚Äôt even get me started on Universe mode. Save resets, messed-up data, and shows malfunctioning are still part of the mix. It has a lot of promise as a mode, yet it always seems half-broken.

Microtransactions are also an unsightly part of the package. Accessing wrestlers, attire, or indeed basic customization items requires either grinding forever or paying more. I am okay with downloadable content as a choice if it adds seriously new content, but gating so much behind either out-of-control grind or additional payment just feels greedy. When you also consider that MyRise is shallow, it makes grinding all the more meaningless.

Now, I don't mean this as a complete rant because you know what, I actually do feel that there are certain things about WWE 2K25 that are laudable. Graphics are good, entrances are great, and commentary, though still repetitive, has gotten better. With friends and especially with couch or with friends you know online, it's still a blast. It still has the magic of creating ridiculous custom fighters and sticking them in goofy stipulation matches. If you are strictly interested in the in-ring action and you don't mind about progression and lacking features and modes, it can still manage a good time. And that's the salvation of the game, it still feels like WWE at its core.

But the problem is everything peripheral to that core feels rushed out or half-finished at least on Steam. We are missing features, the AI is spotty rather than demanding, MyRise feels sparse compared to prior years, and stability at best. Console enthusiasts might be able to declare this one‚Äôs the best 2K game of years, but as a PC gamer, I am unable to say the same. It‚Äôs not that the player cannot play the game, hardly. It‚Äôs that it feels incomplete and somewhat disrespectful as a PC gaming release.
